field_reports.description:
Between 21 July and early August, prolonged torrential rains associated with Tropical Storm No.3 and its remnants caused severe flooding, landslides, and flash floods across the northern provinces of Nghệ An, Sơn La, and Điện Biên. These provinces experienced extensive human and material losses, destruction of critical infrastructure, and displacement of vulnerable communities. 

Nghệ An

  • Casualties: 4 people dead, 4 injured.

  • Housing: Approximately 7,500 houses damaged, collapsed, or buried.

  • Public Infrastructure: Severe damage to schools, clinics, roads, and public buildings.

  • Agriculture: Thousands of hectares of crops and aquaculture areas inundated.

  • Estimated Damage: Approx. VND 3,546 billion (~USD 139 million).

 Điện Biên

  • Casualties: 10 dead, 7 injured (reported between 31 July and 2 August).

  • Housing: 319 houses collapsed, washed away, or urgently relocated.

  • Infrastructure: Roads, bridges, schools, clinics, power lines, and communication systems destroyed.

  • Economic Impact: Estimated loss at least VND 300 billion (~USD 11.8 million).

  • Key areas affected: Na Son, Phình Giàng, and Xa Dung communes.

Sơn La

  • Casualties: 11 total (5 deaths, 1 missing, 5 injured).

  • Housing: Over 850 houses damaged or washed away.

  • Livelihood: 16.5 hectares of aquaculture, crops, and rice fields lost.

  • Isolated Areas: Chiềng Sơ and Huổi Một communes severely affected; many villages isolated due to road collapse and landslides.

  • Infrastructure: Schools, bridges, and irrigation systems destroyed or blocked by landslides.

Thousands of households across the affected provinces have lost their homes, sources of livelihood, and access to essential services such as education and healthcare. Flash floods and landslides have triggered widespread internal displacement, particularly in remote and mountainous areas where entire communities have been cut off. The destruction of water systems and contamination of local water sources have raised serious concerns about hygiene and the potential for waterborne disease outbreaks. In addition, major transportation routes—including national highways and provincial roads—have been severely damaged or blocked, significantly hindering rescue operations and the delivery of humanitarian assistance.

field_reports.description:
Between late July and early August 2025, prolonged heavy rainfall associated with Storm Wipha triggered widespread flooding, flash floods, and landslides across three northern provinces of Viet Nam: Nghệ An, Điện Biên, and Sơn La. The most severely affected areas are remote mountainous communes where rainfall exceeded seasonal norms and overwhelmed already fragile infrastructure. As a result, at least 19 people have died, one is missing, and over 11 others injured. More than 2,000 houses were either damaged or destroyed, while major roads and bridges were washed away, isolating dozens of communities.

Approximately 76,600 to 85,600 people have been directly affected, including thousands who lost homes, access to clean water, food sources, and means of livelihood. In Nghệ An alone, over 58,000 people across 132 villages in 15 communes have been cut off due to road blockages and rising river levels. In Điện Biên and Sơn La, many families were forced to evacuate or take shelter in temporary locations as flash floods inundated homes and farmland. Livelihoods have been heavily disrupted, with thousands of hectares of rice, crops, and livestock lost. Immediate humanitarian needs include shelter, food, safe water, and access to healthcare for displaced and isolated households.

field_reports.description:
In recent days, severe weather caused by the circulation of Typhoon No. 3 has brought heavy rainfall and flash flooding across several northern and central provinces of Vietnam, including Nghe An, Son La, Dien Bien, and Quang Tri.

 

According to VTV Times reporters, on the morning of July 24, four new flooding points were recorded along National Highway 7, passing through Nhan Hoa and Vinh Tuong communes (former Anh Son district, Nghe An province).


Water levels at these locations ranged from 50cm to nearly 1 meter, with strong currents, making it impossible for small vehicles to pass. Many residents were forced to turn back or take longer detours, disrupting daily activities and the transportation of goods.

 

In particular, the section of National Highway 7 running through Cam Thang hamlet in Nhan Hoa commune was submerged under 50cm to 1m of water. Previously, the highway had been completely cut off due to floodwaters rising from the Lam River and local streams. Although the rain has eased, water levels in many areas have yet to recede.

 

Authorities are closely monitoring the situation and advising residents not to travel through deep-flooded areas—especially at night or without proper guidance. Temporary traffic control and mitigation measures are being implemented to ensure the safety of people and property.

Son La Province:

On the night of July 27, torrential rains across 13 communes of the former Song Ma district triggered flash floods and landslides, leaving four people in Chieng So commune dead or missing. Nearly 200 personnel were deployed for search and rescue efforts. Two individuals were swept away in Na Cai 2 village, Chieng So commune.

 

Dien Bien Province:

In Muong Luan commune, a flash flood that struck on the night of July 26 and early morning of July 27 swept away three homes and two community houses, injured two people, and caused major losses of livestock, crops, and infrastructure. Landslides disrupted several inter-village roads. Thanks to early evacuation efforts, no fatalities were reported. Heavy rain and landslides also caused damage and traffic disruptions in Tia Dinh commune.

 

Quang Tri Province:

From July 25 to midday July 27, continuous heavy rains in the southern mountainous region of Quang Tri led to flooding in upstream rivers, isolating multiple inter-commune and inter-village roads. Several spillways were submerged and blocked by rising water. Authorities established checkpoints and barricades to prevent crossings.

 

However, a serious incident occurred on July 26 when four young men ignored safety barriers and attempted to drive across a flooded spillway at Tan Trung village leading to Ban Con, Tan Lap commune. Taking advantage of a break in guard duty around 5:00 PM, they removed the barricades and tried to cross, resulting in their vehicle being swept away by the floodwaters. Fortunately, all four managed to escape from the vehicle safely. The car, however, was lost and has not yet been recovered.

According to reports from the provinces affected heavy rains, flash floods, and landslides from the night of July 23 to July 27, 2025, have caused the following damages:

  • Affected provinces: Lao Cai, Dien Bien, Son La, Quang Tri, Phu Tho, Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, Ninh Binh.

  • Between July 25 and 27, 2025, heavy rains, flash floods, and landslides affected multiple provinces in northern and north-central Vietnam, including Son La, Dien Bien, Lao Cai, Quang Tri, Phu Tho, Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, and Ninh Binh.

    • Human impact: 2 people confirmed dead and 4 missing in Son La; 2 injured in Dien Bien.

    • Housing: Over 1,000 houses damaged or collapsed, including 22 houses destroyed in Son La and 987 houses damaged in Phu Tho, Thanh Hoa, and Nghe An.

    • Evacuation: 66 households were evacuated (40 in Son La, 26 in Lao Cai — all have returned home).

    • Agriculture: Over 54,000 hectares of rice fields were flooded or buried, mainly in Ninh Binh and Thanh Hoa; nearly 17 hectares of fish ponds were swept away.

    • Livestock: More than 400 livestock and 33,000 poultry were killed or swept away.

    • Transport:

      • National and provincial roads reported hundreds of landslide points: 301 in Thanh Hoa and 291 in Nghe An.

      • 5 suspension bridges were washed away.

    • Electricity & telecommunications: 39 power substations affecting 3,677 households in Son La lost power (over half restored); 21 mobile stations remain out of service.

field_reports.description:
As of 22 July 2025, Typhoon Wipha weakened into a tropical depression over northern Viet Nam and later into a low-pressure system along the Viet Nam–Lao border. Despite weakening, the storm brought widespread heavy rainfall, flash floods, and significant agricultural and housing damage, particularly in Thanh Hoa, Nghe An, Phu Tho, Ninh Binh, and Hung Yen provinces.

Initial reports indicate one person missing and another injured due to flash floods in Nghe An. Over 400 houses were damaged, and more than 119,000 hectares of rice fields were flooded. Local authorities are actively operating pumps to prevent waterlogging. The storm also caused the loss of livestock and disrupted daily life in multiple provinces.

In Nghe An Province, extreme rainfall led to record-breaking flood levels along the Ca River. At several hydrological stations, water levels exceeded Alert Level 3 and surpassed historical flood records. The Ban Ve hydropower reservoir also recorded inflows well above its design capacity, raising the risk of downstream flooding, flash floods, and landslides. Authorities remain on high alert as water levels continue to rise in mid- and downstream areas.

As of the morning of July 21, Typhoon Wipha remains at Category 9 but is forecast to strengthen to Category 10-11 as it enters the Gulf of Tonkin, then directly impacts provinces from Quang Ninh to Nghe An.

According to the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting (NCHMF), at 7:00 AM today, the typhoon's center was located over the northern part of the Leizhou Peninsula (China), about 220 km east of Quang Ninh – Hai Phong. The maximum wind speed reached 88 km/h, equivalent to Category 9, with gusts up to Category 11. The storm is moving west-southwest at a speed of 15–20 km/h. By 7:00 AM on July 22, the typhoon is expected to strengthen to Category 10–11, with gusts reaching Category 14, while located over the northern Gulf of Tonkin, and may continue to intensify. It is then forecast to move inland over the provinces from Thanh Hoa to Nghe An and weaken into a low-pressure system over the Upper Laos region.

Forecasted impacts

At Sea:

  • East Sea & Gulf of Tonkin: Winds force 7–11, gusts up to 14; waves 2–6 m; extremely rough seas.
  • High risk in Bạch Long Vi, Co To, Cat Hai, Hon Dau, Hon Ngu with dangerous winds and high waves.

Storm Surge & Coastal Flooding:

  • Surge of 0.5–1.0 m along Hai Phong–Quang Ninh.
  • High tide levels: Hòn Dấu up to 4.1 m, Cua Ong ~4.8 m.
  • Flooding risk from afternoon July 22 in coastal and estuarine zones.

Onshore Hazards (from night July 21):

  • Winds force 7–11, gusts 14 from Quang Ninh to Nghe An; inland gusts up to 8.
  • High damage potential: uprooted trees, power outages, roof damage.

Rainfall & Severe Weather:

  • Heavy to extreme rain July 21–23:
    • NE, Red River Delta, Thanh Hoa–Nghe An: 200–350 mm (locally >600 mm).
    • Hà Tĩnh, northern regions: 100–200 mm (locally >300 mm).
  • Flash flood, landslide, tornado, hail, and lightning risks remain high.
  • Rain persists through July 25 in northern and north-central areas.

Between 19 and 20 July, severe weather—including lightning, tornadoes, and hail—caused significant impacts across 14 provinces in northern, central, and southern Viet Nam. Four fatalities and 11 injuries were reported, primarily due to falling debris, collapsed structures, and lightning strikes. A total of 19 houses were completely destroyed and over 1,700 others sustained damage or were unroofed. Damage was also reported to 32 schools and over 280 hectares of agricultural land, including rice, vegetables, and perennial crops. Additionally, 36 boats were reported capsized. Local authorities are actively responding to the situation and continuing damage assessments.

From 18 to 23 June 2025, heavy rainfall caused widespread flooding and landslides in Bac Kan province, particularly in northern mountainous areas. A total of 277 houses were damaged—most severely in Bach Thong (150 houses), Na Ri (59), and Bac Kan City (13)—with dozens of families urgently evacuated. One person died in a landslide in Ba Be district.

The floods also destroyed aquaculture areas, swept away hundreds of livestock and poultry, and damaged key infrastructure. Around 7,800 m³ of soil and rocks blocked roads, and bridges and drainage systems were damaged in several districts, cutting off access to some areas.

In neighboring provinces, flooding continued to impact Lang Son, where three villages remained isolated as of 24 June, affecting 184 households. Agricultural losses included 495 hectares of inundated rice and crops across Lang Son and Bac Giang, although floodwaters had receded in Thai Nguyen.

field_reports.description:
After making landfall in Quang Ninh province and Hai Phong city with torrential downpours and powerful winds exceeding 200 kilometres per hour on September 7, Super Typhoon Yagi, the strongest storm in the past 30 years, dissipated on Sunday, Sep 8. However, it has triggered prolong downfall combining with large floods from upstream causing the water level of rivers to rise to an alarming level, bringing devastating flooding and landslides in many northern mountainous provinces and urban areas including Ha Noi capital that have resulted in an increased number of casualties.
 
It has been a week after Typhoon Yagi struck, the northern region is still facing severe landslides, large-scale floods and flash floods, as well as dykes and dams breaking and bridges collapsing as a result of heavy and prolonged rains from the Typhoon aftermaths. Between 6-12 Sep, the region suffered heavy to very heavy rainfall, the total rainfall was 250-350mm. At some places, the total rainfall exceed 600mm such as: Nam Cai Luong 3 (Lao Cai) 760mm; An Phu (Yen Bai) 641mm; Pu Danh (Son La) 635mm; Yen Toi (Thai Nguyen) 690mm; Tien Hai (Thai Binh) 754mm; Ky Son (Hoa Binh) 712mm; Huong Son (Hanoi) 651mm. 
 
As of the morning of Sep 14, the Viet Nam Disaster and Dikes Management Authorities (VNDDMA) reported a total of 262 fatalities  and 83 missing, 1,908 injured and over 130,000 people were evacuated caused by the impacts of TC YAGI and Southwest Monsoon in the Northern provinces. Lao Cai, Yen Bai, Cao Bang, Quang Ninh, Hoa Binh, Tuyen Quang, Thai Nguyen... are a few of 12 provinces that suffer the most damage. Three provinces have declared emergencies: Lao Cai, Tuyen Quang and Yen Bai. 
 
According to the same report, there have been 305 dike incidents (an increase of 172 incidents compared to the report on September 12) in 14 provinces/cities. 
 
The typhoon and its aftermaths has damaged 168,253 houses, flooded 73,248 houses; while many shops, residential buildings, offices and schools had their roofs blown off and damaged; many advertising signs, telecommunication poles, mobile broadcasting stations were broken; urban trees were damaged. It also flooded, destroyed more than 250,000 rice, crops and fruit trees while killed almost 2 million poultry, 10'000 livestock and washed away 2,250 aquaculture cages. 
 
The VNDDMA on Sep 12 also report a total of 74,536 households (equivalent to 130,246) were evacuated and displaced. 
 
Currently, despite the flood waters on main rivers across the Northern Delta are receding slowly, warning level of risk due to floods remain very high.
 
The full extent of impact has yet to be determined as damage assessment remains ongoing, while non-stop landslides and flash floods continues throughout the country. Functional forces are struggling and racing to ensure the safety of people's lives while carrying out search and rescue at disasters sites.

field_reports.description:
After super typhoon Yagi made landfall on Saturday, 7 September, it has devastated and left a trail of damage in several northern localities in Viet Nam. The typhoon, strongest one to hit the East Sea in the past three decades, after making landfall in Quang Ninh province and Hai Phong city, continued to wreak havoc, with heavy rains and winds lashing the northern region over 15 hours. It weaken into a tropical depression by 1.00 AM on the following day. However, the Typhoon and its the post-storm circulation have caused a wide range of influence from the Northern region to Thanh Hoa (26 provinces and cities), causing very heavy rain from 200-400mm (from 07-09/9), some places have very heavy rain such as: Nam Cai Luong (Lao Cai) 760mm; Pu Danh (Son La) 607mm; Phong Ho (Yen Bai) 496mm, Yen Toi (Thai Nguyen) 559mm, Nam Dan (Ha Giang) 571mm, Hong An (Cao Bang) 426mm,... This downpour has caused ongoing floods, flash floods, landslides across North of Viet Nam, the most impacted areas were Cao Bang (Nguyen Binh), Lao Cai (Bat Xat, Sa Pa), Hoa Binh (Da Bac), Yen Bai (Van Chan, Luc Yen), Tuyen Quang, Lang Son, Thai Nguyen, Ha Giang,... The flood above alert 3 is in the upper reaches of Luc Nam River (Bac Giang), Thao River (Lao Cai, Yen Bai), Thuong River (Lang Son), Gam River (Tuyen Quang). 
The national meteorological forecasting center forecasted that northern midland mountains from the afternoon of 09-10/9 will face heavy rainfall with common rain of 50-150mm, in some places over 350mm then decrease from the night of 10-11/9 with total rainfall of 40-80mm, in some places over 150mm.
As of 06:00AM on September 10, 2024, the Super typhoon Yagi and its circulation have resulted in at least 104 people died or went missing (65 people died, 39 people were missing), injured more than 750 people and left a trail of devastation across 26 Northern provinces and Thanh Hoa city. The typhoon also damaged more than 48,000 houses, destroyed nearly 190,000 hectares of crops, rices and fruit trees, washed away more than 1,500 aquaculture raft cages, killing more than 690,000 cattle and poultry. Cyclone Yagi has steadily strengthened all week and became a Super Typhoon on the afternoon of Thursday September 5, with maximum winds of 201 kph (125 mph), as it traversed warm open water between the Philippines and China’s Hainan. The National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting has warned that the northern and north-central regions should expect severe weather from Friday's evening through the weekend, with heavy rain and strong wind possible in other regions as well. The Government of provinces by the coastal line banned all vessels from heading to sea, while officials are monitoring storm protection systems and agricultural areas. Small boats are being brought onshore and tied down, while cruises in Hạ Long Bay have been suspended. Heavy rains have caused local floods on small rivers and streams, flash floods, and landslides in many localities in the Northern mountainous region, causing damages to people, houses, production, infrastructure, especially in the provinces of Lai Chau, Yen Bai, Son La, and Lao Cai, Lai Chau, Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai since 2 August 2023. 

 

Since August 4, the region has recorded downpours with rainfalls of 100 - 200mm, even nearly 400mm in some areas, causing flooding on small rivers and springs, flash floods, and landslides in some localities and also resulting in human and property losses, especially in Lai Chau, Yen Bai, and Son La provinces. The National Centre for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting has predicted that downpours will continue in this region from now through August 8, with rainfalls of 50-120mm, even over 180mm, which will continue posing very high risks of floods, flash floods, and landslides.

From 5 August 5 to 18:00 on 6 August, downpours and floods caused 10 casualties in northern mountainous and midland localities, including seven in Lai Chau, two in Yen Bai and one in Son La, along with heavy property losses, reported the Standing Office of the National Steering Committee.

 

According to a report from the National Commanding Committee for Natural Disaster Prevention and Control (NDPC) of Lai Chau Province, floods have caused 4 deaths and 3 injuries in Ta Mung commune, Khoen On commune, Than Uyen district, affecting 75 houses, of which 39 are in Nam Nhun district, 25 are in Than Uyen district, 10 are in Phong Tho district, the rest are in Sin Ho district. Over 3ha of rice and tea has been eroded and completely buried.

 

Floods have caused subsidence and landslides of many roads in the province with a volume of about 23,000 cubic meters of soil and rock. About 14 km of affected roads include: landslides, road talus, longitudinal trenches and some broken sections causing traffic jams on National Highway 4H at Km 272+200, Km 272+922, Km15+ 420, Km293+930, Km270+300, Km196+090. Flood also caused landslides and damaged 4 irrigation works in Than Uyen district.

A dam containing 1.2 million cubic meters of water, a volume equivalent to 480 Olympic-size swimming pools, in Dak Nong Province has showed signs of cracks following days of heavy rain. Dak Nong province has declared an emergency on natural disasters to handle situations. According to the Provincial People's Committee (PPC), from the end of 6 – 7 August, the area experienced prolonged heavy rains, the total rainfall at Dak Ha station was nearly 400 mm.

 

By 7 August, the cracks on the foot of the dam spanned around 500 m and were around 150 m deep, and showed no signs of abating. On the right side of the dam, around 10 ha of crops are sinking. An estimated 1 million cubic meters of soil has risk of landslides. The dam itself also has large cracks spanning 10-20 cm. The Dak N’Ting reservoir project cost around VND137 billion ($5.78 million), was built to irrigate around 700 ha of crops in Quang Son Commune. To ensure safety, authorities have blocked entrances into the dam area and evacuated 34 families with around 100 people.

At around 8:30 a.m on 8 August, the stream of blackish water coming from a reservoir that contains waste from the extraction of copper from ores rushed towards Ta Phoi Commune, Lao Cai province. The wastewater inundated houses and the commune's People’s Committee office. A local said the stream came quickly and without warning, so they could only escape with their lives, not having enough time to take their belongings.

 The Lao Cai People’s Committee said long-lasting rains have contributed to the breakage, and the exact amount of damage incurred is being evaluated. Lao Cai has been seeing rains over the past week, with the highest amount of rainfall seen on Monday night at 80 mm, according to the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting. Heavy rains have triggered erosion at over 140 locations in Lao Cai, damaging more than 30 houses and flooding more than 110 others. Over 340 ha of crops and around 2 ha of aquaculture have also been damaged.

On the night of October 11, Typhoon Kompasu entered the East Sea. At 7:00 a.m. on October 12, the location of the storm's center was at about 18.9 degrees north latitude; 119.0 degrees East longitude, 850km northeast of Hoang Sa archipelago. The strongest wind in the area near the center of the storm is at level 10-11 to level 13 gust

It is forecasted that in the next 24 hours, the storm will move quickly to the west, with a speed of about 25-30km per hour. By 7:00 am on October 13, the location of the storm's center will be at about 19.0 degrees North latitude; 112.8 degrees East longitude, about 320km northeast of the Paracel Islands. The strongest wind in the area near the center of the storm is at level 11 to level 14 gust.

Danger zone in the East Sea within 24 hours is from latitude 16.0 to 22.0 north latitude; and 110.5 degrees East longitude.

On October 12, from Quang Tri to Binh Thuan, there were thunderstorms with moderate to heavy rain. Total rainfall is 20-50mm, and over 70mm in some places. From October 12 to October 13, in the Central Highlands and southern provinces, there is moderate, heavy rain to severe rain locally, with a total rainfall of 70-140mm, and over 180mm in some places (heavy rain is concentrated in the afternoon and the evening).

Disaster risk level warning: level 3.

At 3a.m of October 13, the water level on Dong Nai river in Ta Lai is at 113.16m which is 0.16m above the alarming level 3. It is forecasted that in the morning of October 13, the water level will continue to rise, potentially reaching a peak of 113.5m, which is 0.5m above the alarming level 3.

From the afternoon of October 13 to October 15, on the rivers of the Northern region from Thanh Hoa to Quang Tri, there is a possibility of a flood. During this flood, the flood peaks on small rivers and streams in the North, upstream rivers from Thanh Hoa to Ha Tinh, and rivers in Quang Binh and Quang Tri could reach an alarming level of 1-2, some rivers were above the alarming level 2. The flood peaks on Thao river (Yen Bai province) and Boi river (Hoa Binh province) have reached alarming level 2 and above level 2. Downstream of the main rivers in the Northern region, from Thanh Hoa to Ha Tinh, is still below the alarming level 1.

The Northern region and Quang Tri province have heavy rain, in some places it rains severely with the common rainfall from 100-150mm, over 200mm in some places. The area from Thanh Hoa to Quang Binh has very heavy rain with the common rainfall of 200-300mm, and over 350mm in some places.

The Central Highlands and the South have moderate to heavy rain and thunderstorms, with the rainfall of 30-80mm, and over 100mm in some places.

During thunderstorms, there is a possibility of whirlwind, lightning, and hail. There is a risk of flash floods, landslides in mountainous areas and local flooding in low-lying areas and riverside.

Disaster risk warning level due to heavy rain, whirlwind, lightning, and hail: Level 1

On 14th of October 2021, the storm decreased into tropical depression.

At 7:00 a.m. on October 14, the location of the center of the tropical depression was at about 19.0 degrees North latitude; 107.4 degrees East longitude, about 220km from Thanh Hoa, about 230km from Nghe An, and about 200km from Ha Tinh. The strongest wind in the area near the center of the tropical depression is at level 6 to 7, with level 9 gust. 

Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces have heavy to severe rain, with common rainfall from 30-70mm. There is higher precipitation in some stations such as: Hanh Lam (104mm), Thanh Thuy (77mm), Con Cuong (73mm); Huong Giang (82mm), Dau Lien (82mm), Huong Dien (72mm). The provinces such as Thanh Hoa, the Northern Delta, the North West and the Central Highlands have scattered rain with the average rainfall less than 30mm.

From October 14-15, upstream rivers from Thanh Hoa to Ha Tinh provinces, rivers in Quang Binh and Quang Tri reaches alarming level 1 – alarming level 2 and above level 2. Downstream of the main rivers from Nghe An and Ha Tinh provinces reaches alarming level 1.

According to the report from the National Steering Committee for Disaster Prevention and the Provincial Red Cross Chapters, damages caused by heavy rain, flooding, and landslides in the Northern Viet Nam from the night of 22 May to 24 May 2025 are as follows:

  • Human impact: One person was injured by lightning in Cao Bang.
  • Housing: 32 houses were damaged (Tuyen Quang: 23; Lao Cai: 03; Cao Bang: 04; Bac Kan: 02).
  • Agriculture: A total of 207.5 hectares of rice and crops were damaged (Tuyen Quang: 159.8 ha; Lao Cai: 3.3 ha; Yen Bai: 3.2 ha; Cao Bang: 11.4 ha; Bac Kan: 30 ha); 6 livestock and 206 poultry were reported dead.
  • Transportation: 56 road sections in Lao Cai, Yen Bai, and Tuyen Quang experienced minor landslides, with a total volume of approximately 5,883 cubic meters; one temporary bridge in Y Ty commune, Bat Xat district, Lao Cai was washed away.
  • Irrigation: 136 meters of canals were damaged (Tuyen Quang: 92 m; Lao Cai: 20 m).
  • Other damages: Minor damages were also reported in the irrigation, transportation, and power supply sectors.

Information forecast announced that on May 26, from southern Nghe An to Quang Binh, there will be moderate to heavy rain and thunderstorms, with localized very heavy rainfall. Rainfall amounts are generally expected to range from 20–50mm, with some areas exceeding 100mm. From Quang Tri to Quang Ngai, scattered showers and thunderstorms are expected, with localized heavy rain ranging from 10–30mm, and some areas receiving more than 50mm.

In addition, during the afternoon and evening of May 26, the Southern region is forecast to have scattered showers and thunderstorms, with localized heavy rain ranging from 10–30mm, and in some areas, over 50mm.

From 6 October 2020 the Central region of Viet Nam experienced prolonged, heavy rains that have caused severe and widespread flooding and landslides in eight provinces. This is due to the combination of numerous weather systems – the Inter Tropical Convergence Zone combining with cold air as well as tropical storms Linfa and Nangka. Tropical Storm Linfa made landfall in Quang Nam and Quang Ngai provinces in Central Viet Nam in the morning of 11 October 2020 while Tropical Storm Nangka made landfall in the morning of 14 October 2020 in the northern provinces of Viet Nam which brought along a further 300 – 450 millimeters of rain into the country. On 16 October 2020, another tropical depression (Tropical Depression INVEST 94W) made landfall in the central provinces of Viet Nam. The tropical depression had weakened into a low-pressure area and dissipated after landfall.

By 24 October 2020, 130 deaths were reported and a further 18 people were missing, according to the Viet Nam Disaster Management Authority (VNDMA). Over 310,000 houses have been flooded, affecting 1.3 million people. Authorities estimated that a total of seven million people have been exposed to the storms, and some five million people are likely to experience worsening conditions because of the flooding situation.

In the coming days more rainfall has been forecasted to hit the central region, while hydropower plants began releasing water from reservoirs. Typhoon Molave is predicted to make landfall on already-flooded regions of Viet Nam on 28 October 2020. Affected provinces include Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, Quang Tri, Thura Thien Hue, Da Nang, Quang Nam and Quang Ngai.
